listitem.para: Creates a scrollbar control. Scrollbars let the user select a value by sliding a "scoller" along a bar that represents a range of possible values. The position of the scrollbar is often linked to a "static" control that informs the user of its setting, but this is not required.
Before a scrollbar can be used, you must set the range and initial value using SCROLLBARSET.

The orientation (vertical or horizontal) of the scrollbar is determined by the longest dimension. That is, if width > height, then the scrollbar will be horizontal. Otherwise, the scrollbar will be vertical.
The parent input is the name of the window that will own the new scrollbar.
The name input identifies the new scrollbar and MUST be a unique word.
The xpos input is the X coordinate where the upper left-hand corner of the new scrollbar is placed.
The ypos input is the Y coordinate where the upper left-hand corner of the new scrollbar is placed.
The width input is the width of the new scrollbar, in pixels.
The height input is the height of the new scrollbar, in pixels.

The callback input is an instruction list that is run whenever the user adjusts the position of the scollbar. One common use for the callback input is to inform the user of what the value has been selected.

programlisting.userinput:
; create a scrollbar in a new window: WINDOWCREATE "main "mywindow "mytitle 0 0 100 100 [] SCROLLBARCREATE "mywindow "myscroll 25 25 50 25 [SETHEADING SCROLLBARGET "myscroll] SCROLLBARSET "myscroll 0 360 0 Move the scrollbar and observe what happens to the turtle WINDOWDELETE "mywindow
; create a scrollbar on graphics window: SCROLLBARCREATE "main "myscroll 25 25 100 25 [SETHEADING SCROLLBARGET "myscroll] SCROLLBARSET "myscroll 0 360 0 Move the scrollbar and observe what happens to the turtle WINDOWDELETE "main
